column4: hey guys, anyone know of a good guide i can follow to setup a vbox?
: What's a vbox?
Virtualbox is _easy_.   There is a guide on the SUN website, and after reading that, I had no problems.  Or just try it.
What do you mean by "seamlessly"?
I just use the one on the SUN website.  I don't have a URL handy.  One read, and everything became obvious.  :)
OK, did you get something like a "hit F12 to select boot media" down at the bottom?
and then that goes away and you have a blank screen?
OK.  No problem.   It _is_ easy.  You just have to put a virtual boot CDROM into the virtual drive.  :)
which you can do easily enough- or map the virtual cd to a .iso somewhere in your hard drive.    Either works, but the hard drive is faster.
Do you have a .iso of the operating system you want to load into the empty virtual machine?
one important concept you might be missing: a virtual machine is the _same_ as a real copper-and-silicon machine.  It knows _nothing_ till you boot and install the operating system.
for XP?  Or for Ubuntu?  Or what?
a .iso is the image of a CD you have on a hard drive.... it's the equivalent of the CD, but not yet turned into pits in the plastic.
sure.  That would work.  Or your Ubuntu CD.  Maybe start with Ubuntu first, bfcause you already have it running and you know how it works.

Yep.  That's what I do when I want to play.  If you hose the virtual machine, no harm/no foul, you delete it (or revert it to a snapshot) and the hosage goes magically away.  Meanwhile, you can be IRCing safely along in another VM.  :)
So that's why I say "try it with Ubuntu in the virtual machine first".
(note- I have to do this with my wife, so we can have her running XP in a VM in her Mac and we can ditch the Dell boat anchor!)
Anyway, wanna give this a spin?
Got your Ubuntu install CD?
Yep.  the .iso you downloaded works fine.
No problem.  32 or 64, both work under VB.
is it on your hard drive now?  Or do you want to grab the CD you used?

how much disk and RAM does your real machine have?

yes, you canincrease it later, but let's keep it easy for now.

No problem

whoa.  Beefy.  :)
Core 2 duo?
should be fine then.  What's your status bar at?

OK.  Nice HW.  Anyway, you should now have a machine listed in the sidebar.  Click on it once, then click "settings" (the orange gear).
I would leave most of it alone... but lessee...  General > Basic, give it 32 MB of vram,
General>advanced,  checkoff "Floppy, CDROM, Hard Disk", enable ACPI, enable VTx, enable nested paging, enable NX
no other changes on General.
Hard Disks: no changes.
CD/DVD > HERE is where you have to set the boot media.  Either point it at the CDROM (andput your Ubuntu CD in) or point it at the .iso on the hard drive.).   This is the magic part.  :)
OK.  Lemme check the rest of settings...

you might want to enable audio.  :-)  And yes,  a new Windoze machine needs to go thru the install procedure- and the WGA authentication!  So write down the volume ID and Ethernet MAC because you might need to recreate it.
Yeah.  That's the way ti goes.  :)
Wish I had one.  I have licenses.  But the f***** WGA annoys the heck out of me, which is another reason I run Linux.  :)
anyway, you should be ready.  Click "OK" to exit settings, then (assuming the new VM is still highlighted) click the green START arrow, and off it should boot!

it will produce a window that looks just like Ubuntu doing a virgin install - which it is, inside the virtual disk you already created.  Don't let it scare ya; the virtual machine cannot get outside of that.
tell me later.  :)
OK, how's it working?
Yeah.  go back to Settings>CD/DVDROM
Tell me what you have in Settings>DVDROM.
er, tell me what you have in Settings > CD/DVD-ROM ?
OK, that's right.
OK, back to General > Advanced.  What's your boot order- and is CD/DVD checked off?
(you might need to move CD/DVD to the top of the list.  )
no you don't need to F12.  Just check the CD/DVD and it will find it.
isn't it an absolute GAS to see the bootup sequence happening in that little window?  :)
yeah.  It's a gas.  :)
Just be sure to take snapshots and back up those snapshots!
Yes, you can.  One guy I know got something like twenty levels deep before he got bored.  :)
actually, the snapshot is NOT bootable.  It is _resumeable_, so essentially it's insta-boot (like resuming from suspend-to-RAM).
you don't even need to go thru the bootup sequence... it wakes up exactly where you left off.
Oh, shoulda warned you about that.  Down in the lower right corner there is a logo that tells you what button will release the mouse and KB.
also, the first time it happens on any VM, it pops a warning box you have to click thru that says "here is how you un-capture the mouse".
Lemme guess, you clicked thru the clickthru box.
Depends on what you have it set for.  You can change it.  I have mine set for "right ALT" here on the MB.
You should be able to.  It might get a little slow but it should still work.  Give it a try- if it fails, delete the virtual machine and try again .

note- BE CAREFUL to always use the menu to add/delete virtual machines, don't use "rm" from the command line, because there's a lot of bookkeeping inside VBox that depends on the filenames being intact and there.
No problem then.  To delete the virtual disks, you use VirtualBox > File > Virtual Media Manager " and do it in there.  That keeps all of the pointers correct.
